Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Impacts-

A useful long term vision of the chemical industry integrates the use of modern biotechnology and chemical catalysis to engineer systems where everyday fuels and chemicals are produced from renewable resources. The vision of this award, made to Professors Brian F. Pfleger, Christos Maravelias, Katherine D. McMahon, Thatcher W. Root and Andrew Greenberg of the University of Wisconsin-Madison is to develop and evaluate a biorefinery strategy using cyanobacteria to produce compounds that support a chemical industry based on photosynthesis. It will demonstrate methods for producing high-value commodity chemicals from CO2 and sunlight that will replace current petrochemical-based processes. Key fundamental questions that will guide the establishment of such a sustainable chemical economy based on photosynthetic cyanobacteria include: 1) What chemicals, i.e. final products or intermediates of value, should be made by living systems to optimize a chemical industry based on photosynthesis? 2) At what rate and fraction of theoretical yield can cyanobacteria produce target compounds?
3) What process parameters are critical to effectively scale up photosynthetic bioreactors from the laboratory to industrial size? Is there a limit to the feasible size of a photosynthetic biorefinery? 4) Can a photosynthetic biorefinery be integrated with waste remediation (e.g. municipal wastewater treatment) to simultaneously meet sustainability and environmental objectives? This award details a number of key features in the fundamental science and technology supporting their photosynthetic biorefinery vision, and is made through the Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation Program at NSF.

Broader Impacts-

In the long term the proposed work will contribute to restructuring the chemical industry away from fossil fuels and towards renewable carbon sources. In addition establishing photosynthetic biorefineries is a route for achieving energy security and maintaining national defense. Deployment of successful, commercial photosynthetic biorefineries could generate a sustainable source of fuels and chemicals without altering current agricultural practices.

Impact on education and outreach has many individual strategies proposed by the PIs, including a)Integrating technoeconomic analysis and LCA into CBE process design and lab courses; b)Providing independent study and research experiences for undergraduates in the university labs; c) Mentoring an interdisciplinary undergraduate synthetic biology research team (iGEM); d) Providing summer research experiences for high-school students and teachers; and e) Recruiting students from underrepresented groups through successful, existing UW-Madison programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Emerging Frontiers Project was focused on developing and evaluating strategies for deploying cyanobacteria as biocatalysts in photosynthetic biorefineries. The ultimate goal of this research is to develop sustainable routes for producing chemicals from sunlight, carbon dioxide, and other waste materials. The interdisciplinary project team provided metabolic engineering, reactor design, environmental engineering, and systems optimization expertise that was integrated to develop new tools, models, datasets, and interdisciplinary researchers. In terms of intellectual merit outcomes, the team assembled a genetic engineering toolbox for a fast-growing cyanobacteria, engineered strains of capable of producing elevated levels of lactate, lysine, and glycogen as model products, models of carbon fixation, cell growth, and bioreactor scale-up, datasets for evaluating cell growth in wastewater and in raceway ponds, and technoeconomic frameworks for selecting target products, designing biorefineries, and evaluating their performance. These outcomes were disseminated through peer-reviewed research articles, intellectual property filings, and presentations at scientific meetings. We anticipate that the project outcomes will influence both researchers and industry as the search for sustainable chemical production technologies continues. In general terms, we found that cyanobacteria can be readily engineered to redirect upwards of 20% of fixed carbon dioxide to metabolic products without severely impacting growth rates. However, the lower cell titers and corresponding product titers relative to traditional fermentations increase the challenge of purifying products from cell cultures.

In terms of Broader Impact outcomes, the project partially supported 11 PhD students and 1 MS student pursue their thesis research. All have successfully defended and earned degrees. Some have moved on to industrial careers in biotechnology, chemical engineering, or consulting. Others are aspiring academics and have secured post-doctoral positions. In addition to graduate students, the project supported 7 post-doctoral fellows. Two of which are now faculty and others are pursuing industrial, entrepreneurial, and academic careers. The project also supported 10 UW-Madison undergraduates pursue independent study. Of these students, five are currently pursuing graduate degrees.

With supplemental funding, we hosted an EFRI-REM program during the summers of 2014-2018. In total, we supported 29 students during the course of the program. 86% of REM participants were female, 45% from underrepresented groups. During the course of the REM program 88% of the eligible REM students attended the annual EFRI-REM meeting in February at the AAAS ERN meeting.  During that time five REM students won best poster awards for their EFRI-REM research projects.  Over the course of the EFRI project 83% of the participants are attending PhD programs or plan to enroll in them upon completion of their BS degree.
